    HTML Panel Tips #23: JavascriptObfuscator API Gulp.js Plugin

    When developing HTML Panels, Iâ€™m always quite fanatic about code privacy: for a variety of reasons, I donâ€™t want users to peek into my files. Lately, Iâ€™ve found particularly effective the obfuscation provided by javascriptobfuscator.com â€“ which, surprisingly, works equally fine with both JavaScript and ExtendScript.

    Their paid tier offers the possibility to access it through HTTP â€“ a good candidate for Gulp automation. Since thereâ€™s no ready-made plugin available on the internet, Iâ€™ve ventured into building one; which Iâ€™m going to share with you in this post. Before going into the technical details of Gulp plugins, let me recap very briefly my point of view on code privacy.

    1. HTML Panels should protect both JS and JSX, and JSX is known to be particularly resistant to aggressive minification and/or obfuscation.
    2. To my experience, free obfuscation services are not that much reliable: even the apparently ugliest result can be automatically beautified in such a way that at least part of the code logic is exposed. Moreover, some of them are known to inject malicious code in the process.
    3. Â Iâ€™ve evaluated two or three different options, and Iâ€™ve finally chosen the one Iâ€™ll talk about. Iâ€™m not sponsored in any way â€“ alas :-)
    4. No, JSXBIN isnâ€™t as secure as it was in the past.

    Please note that Iâ€™ll assume Gulp knowledge â€“ Iâ€™ve already written about it here, please check that if you find yourself lost. That said, letâ€™s see the example code they provide on this page, that Iâ€™ll use as a starting point â€“ itâ€™s theÂ Javascript Obfuscator API Example Project (HTTP + JSON API). The following is found in a script tag of an html page.

    Letâ€™s inspect this. First, you need your API Key and API Password, that you can find in your JavascriptObfuscator dashboard, as soon as youâ€™ve subscribed to one of the paid tiers. A projÂ object is created, and some properties assigned: your API data, the project name, and a series of parameters that will drive the obfuscation process. In this case, ReplaceNameÂ set toÂ trueÂ (line 6). In the same call, you can send for processing more that one single file: they must be wrapped with an object (here item0 and item1), which actual code is found in the FileCode property (lines 11-17).

    Then theyâ€™re both stored into an array that is assigned to the proj.Items property. Next, a standard XMLHttpRequestÂ of type POST is sent, passing the stringified proj object (line 26). The response is then showed in a couple of div elements in the page. Enough for this example. The kind of API that Iâ€™d like to consume in my real code is as follows â€“ this comes directly, yet slightly simplified, from my gulpfile.js

    Iâ€™m passing two filesÂ in the source array â€“ the ones Iâ€™m interested in deep obfuscating: the main application JS, and the only JSX of the Panel. The processed result is going to be saved in the dist folder, keeping the same directories structure. As you see, Iâ€™m requiring './jsobfuscator': this means that Iâ€™ve created in the root folder a jsobfuscator.jsÂ file, which contains my actual Gulp plugin. The entire code is as follows, read along for a walkthrough.

    Before going any further, check this Writing a Gulp Plugin documentation page as a way to orient yourself: Iâ€™ll point out the main problems Iâ€™ve run into as a total Gulp plugins beginner, that Iâ€™ve been able to solve after a good deal of head scratching time. First, you need to require some modules: the native fs, stream, andÂ http, plus through2, gulp-util, and vinylÂ â€“ install them:

    Iâ€™m exporting a single function, that returns (line 84) the transform function passed through the through.obj() method: this is the way a Gulp plugin works.

    The transform function (line 10) is exactly where everything happens. Iâ€™ve recreated there the proj object youâ€™ve seen in the demo file, passing a lot more parameters. These ones (lines 21-29, like MoveStrings, DeepObfuscate, etc.) should mimic the setupÂ illustrated in the screenshot at right, that comes from the JavascriptObfuscator Windows-only GUI.

    Thatâ€™s what youâ€™re allowed to set with a Basic membership ($19 per month). Iâ€™m not 100% sure Iâ€™ve been able to replicate everything: if you have a better understanding of the parameters, please let me know in the comments. Next, Iâ€™ve created the wrapper object (appJS, line 31) that will contain the plain code to be obfuscated: please note that the FileCode property this time canâ€™t be just equal to file, which is a peculiar object called Vinyl FileÂ â€“ what your Plugin should receive and, eventually, return. Instead, youâ€™re interested into the contents prop of the Vinyl File, which happens to be a Buffer:Â so you need to stringify it, passing the correct encoding ('utf8').

    At line 35,Â appJS is inserted in the proj.Items array; Iâ€™m then creating a postData variable, that holds the String Iâ€™ll eventually need to POST to the Â JavascriptObfuscator server â€“ the stringified version of the entire proj object. Line 41-49,Â the options objectÂ will be needed in the request at line 80: I have to specify the host (no prepended https), path, method, and headers. Without 'Content-Type' and 'Content-Length'Â (see this StackOverflow thread for the Buffer.byteLength() methodÂ used to calculate the latter) the request will fail. Line 49,Â postCallback is called when the request is dispatched.

    As soon as data is coming, i.e.Â response.on('data'), a string is formed. When the response is terminated, i.e.Â response.on('end'),Â Iâ€™mÂ parsing the received JSON string into an object (line 62). If you want to log it â€“ or log anything to debug your code â€“ use the gutil.log() function, that you can find in the code comments here and there. The horribly, properly obfuscated string is foundÂ in theÂ resObj.Items[0].FileCode prop, hurray! The only problem is, as Iâ€™ve mentioned earlier, that your Gulp plugin needs to return a Vinyl File. Hence, a brand new Vinyl File called jsFile is created (line 66) using current working directory, base, and path from the original file. What about the contents? You cannot stick in there theÂ resObj.Items[0].FileCode String, because contents must be a Stream. Thanks to the holy StackOverflow, Iâ€™ve learned that a ReadableÂ (line 64) can turn String into Stream, and Iâ€™m a happy camper now.

    Last but not least, this Vinyl file must be pushed down the line, for the Gulp Plugin to work. Was I not into a callback, nested in a function, which in turn is nested into the main transform function, I would have used this.push(jsFile). But I happen to be at a location where this is not what it used to be: thatâ€™s the why Iâ€™ve stored it (line 15) into the that variable. So that.push(jsFile), line 75. At the very end, you need to run the transformâ€™s callback (line 76), and you can call quit.

    The above took me more than a full day of work to figure outâ€¦ Itâ€™s been a self-taught crash course on Gulp Plugins â€“ worth sharing to you and my future selfÂ when Iâ€™ll have forgotten every juicy detail of it; in aboutâ€¦ a couple of months maybe? There is plenty of room for improvement â€“ I would have liked to merge multiple source files not into a single file, but into a single http request: splitting the various input files into several elements of theÂ proj.Items array. Yet, I have no idea how to do so (suggestions in the comments are welcome!). Error checking is completely missing, and so on and so forth. Rough as it is, it works; and every second saved from manual labor is worth the effort, isnâ€™t it?
